{{lang|ja|丸亀城}} |partof = |location = [[Marugame, Kagawa|Marugame]], [[Kagawa Prefecture]], [[Japan]] |coordinates = |image = [[File:Marugame Castle08s3872.jpg|250px]] |caption = The ''tenshu'' (keep) of Marugame Castle |type = |built = |builder = [[Nara Motoyasu]] |materials = |height = |used = 1587–1615; 1644–1870 |demolished = |condition = |ownership = |controlledby = |garrison = |commanders = |occupants = |battles = |events = }} {{Nihongo|'''Marugame Castle'''|丸亀城|Marugame-jō}}, also known as '''Kameyama Castle''' and Horai Castle, is a ''hirayama shiro'' ([[Japanese castle|castle]] situated on a hill surrounded by a plain) located in [[Marugame, Kagawa|Marugame]], [[Kagawa Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. ==History== The first [[fortifications]] built on the site that would later become Marugame castle were erected by the Nara clan led by [[Nara Motoyasu]], who in turn were retainers of the [[Hosokawa clan]] during the Muromachi Period. Little evidence of this exists today, however. [[File:Takahama Kyoshi monument in Marugame castle.JPG|left|155px|thumb|A monument by [[Kyoshi Takahama]]]] The roots of the current castle lie in 1587, when Marugame Castle was the residence of the lord of the [[Sanuki Province]], [[Ikoma Chikamasa]].[http://www.jcastle.info/castle/profile/9-Marugame-Castle Marugame Castle] In 1597, Chikamasa constructed [[Takamatsu Castle (Sanuki)|Takamatsu Castle]] as his new location from which to rule from and turned Marugame Castle over to his son, [[Ikoma Kazumasa]].[http://gojapan.about.com/od/attractioninshikoku/p/kameyamakoen.htm Kameyama Koen Park in Kagawa - attractions in Shikoku Japan] Kazumasa immediately began renovating the castle, and made it into a formidable fortification. In 1615, however, due to a shogunal decree that each province could have but one castle, Marugame Castle was dismantled. In 1641, a small section of western Sanuki (including what was left of Marugame Castle) was granted, as a fief, to [[Yamazaki Ieharu]] for his valor in the 1638 [[Shimabara Rebellion]]. Ieharu re-built the castle on the ruins of the original and most of what stands today dates from his reconstruction, which he completed in 1644. However, in 1658, the castle was turned over to the [[Kyōgoku clan]]. They further improved the castle by rebuilding the Otemmon complex in 1670. The Kyōgoku managed to retain control of the castle until the Imperial Government seized control of it during the [[Meiji Restoration]]. In 1869, a fire swept through the castle and destroyed many of the buildings.[http://library.thinkquest.org/C001119/tour/parse.php3?src=marugame Marugame Castle] This was followed by another spate of destruction when the Imperial Government destroyed much of what remained in 1870. Shortly afterward, the outer moat was filled in. ==Today== [[File:Marugame Castle01.jpg|thumb|A view from distance.]] Besides the stone walls, few of the buildings at Marugame Castle still stand today, though the Ote Ichino Gate, Ote Nino Gate, and the ''[[tenshu]]'' ([[keep]]), which underwent a major restoration in 1950, still stand. All of these original buildings have been declared [[Important Cultural Properties of Japan|Important Cultural Properties]] by the Japanese Government. Marugame castle is one of only a dozen Japanese castles to still have an original wooden ''tenshu'' built before 1860.[http://www.city.marugame.lg.jp/english/tourism/index.html Marugame City Official Website Tourism] The castle is preserved in Kameyama Park, and its museum is housed in the ''tenshu''.[http://www.japanvisitor.com/index.php?cID=426&pID=1650 Marugame Castle :: Japan Visitor] == References == {{reflist}} == Literature == *{{cite book |title=Castles of the Samurai:Power & Beauty| last=Mitchelhill |first=Jennifer |year=2013|publisher=Kodansha|location=USA| ISBN=978-1568365121}} *{{cite book | title=Japanese Castles| last=Motoo| first=Hinago| year=1986| pages= 200 pages| publisher=Kodansha| location=Tokyo| isbn=0-87011-766-1}} == External links == {{commonscat-inline|Marugame Castle}} {{coord|34.286191|133.800194|format=dms|display=title|type:landmark_region:JP_scale:10000}} {{100 Fine Castles of Japan}} [[Category:Castles in Kagawa Prefecture]] [[Category:Museums in Kagawa Prefecture]] [[Category:History museums in Japan]] [[Category:Important Cultural Properties of Japan]] [[Category:Historic Sites of Japan]]
